6.text:
>>CHAIR: Andrew Jimson described Jeremy Hunt
as a man who offered his enemies no point

11.text:
of attack. The health secretary he said wore
an armour of smiling friendliness. Spoke a

18.text:
language of impenetrable blandness and had
devised an NHS policy which focused people's

24.text:
minds on how to improve the service not on
how to defend it against some imaginary plan

29.text:
to flog it off. This makes Hunt he said a
difficult man to write about. We feral beasts

34.text:
prefer to sink our teeth into a disaster a
crisis or at last a gaff. As far as I can

41.text:
see I'm sorry to keep on quoting Andrew Jimson
but he said I apologise to anyone but I have

46.text:
never managed to see anyone who’s written
an amusing profile of Mr. Hunt as health secretary

52.text:
he has achieved the extraordinary feat of
making his portfolio seem quite dull. Secretary

61.text:
of State you have lived through and survived
one junior doctors strike, the first ever

65.text:
in NHS history, there are others looming.
A new contract imposed on 54,000 junior doctors

72.text:
in the NHS and now as I say series of rolling
strikes. Hardly a quiet life; do you think

79.text:
Andrew Jimson would change his mind now?
JEREMY HUNT: Thank you Tim a wonderful introduction

86.text:
and Andrew Jimson also described me as the
politician most similar to a children's TV

92.text:
presenter which I think was meant to be from
a political journalist a big insult but I

99.text:
think I've given him and other people a bit
more to write about for actually very unfortunate

103.text:
reasons in the last year but thank you for
introducing me thank you everyone for inviting

109.text:
me to Expo and congratulations again on on
an absolutely fantastic show. I think it goes

116.text:
from strength to strength. We have got new
and exciting things, new faces here this year

122.text:
but the buzz is there and I think that says
a huge amount about the way things are really

130.text:
changing in the NHS behind the headlines and
in a way that sometimes isn't picked up in

136.text:
in what people read in the papers. I am also
delighted to come back here as Health Secretary

144.text:
after our change of Prime Minister; there
were one or two moments when I wasn't sure

149.text:
I was going to be coming back as Health Secretary.
I used to say that I had the safest job in

159.text:
the Cabinet because no other Cabinet minister
wanted it but I'm not sure that it did feel

165.text:
like that at every moment during the course
of this year. But what I would say is looking

171.text:
after public services for the people who vote
us in at elections is always core business

180.text:
for any government but health is different.
It's got a bigger budget; our budget is double

188.text:
the education budget, 3 times the defence
budget, 10 times the police budget. It arouses

196.text:
bigger passions, if you ask people in survey
after survey what makes them most proud to

202.text:
be British they say it's the NHS ahead of
the royal family ahead of armed services ahead

207.text:
of the BBC it's right there and indeed we
are more proud of our health system; 58 per

215.text:
cent of us are proud of the NHS compared to
39 per cent of Germans so it's a connection

220.text:
that runs very, very deep. And the other big
difference is that we are much much more affected

227.text:
by changes in technology and science than
any other sectors. Whether it's this morning’s

234.text:
story of an exciting new immunotherapy drug
for pancreatic cancer that shows great promise;

243.text:
whether it's the incredible potential of genomics.
A couple of young girls recently were diagnosed

252.text:
at Great Ormond Street having a rare genetic
disease that they hadn’t been able to understand

256.text:
what it is for their entire lives and genomics
has made that possible and that's a totally

263.text:
extraordinary change. Or it’s the changes
that we're about to see. Bob alluded to some

270.text:
them in his inspirational talk earlier this
morning. But when I went and met Bob Wachter

277.text:
this time last year in San Francisco, on that
same visit I met scientists who described

285.text:
how in one drop of blood there are 300,000
bio markers and they predict that within the

294.text:
next decade rather than going to a doctor
for a diagnosis most of the time we will taking

300.text:
a monthly blood test at home which will analyse
those 300,000 bio markers and we'll be able

306.text:
to spot disease much, much earlier than we
are able to at the moment. And many people

311.text:
think that the changes that we are about to
see in healthcare will transform humanity

319.text:
by even more than the internet has done over
the last 15 years and so in that context it's

328.text:
very important to be clear-headed about where
we want to go with the NHS, which is why Expo

336.text:
is actually a very, very big statement of
intent. And I would say that if you look at

343.text:
the internet it's a very important comparison.
Most of the changes that the internet has

350.text:
brought about, they’ve improved customer
service in many areas but they are essentially

356.text:
driven by efficiency. So if you look at the
airline industry their saving about 2 billion

360.text:
pounds a year in this country because of the
move to booking our tickets on-line and so

366.text:
on. The banking industry now 90 per cent of
transactions done electronically; they are

372.text:
100 times cheaper than the old days when we
used to go to the bank with our cheques and

378.text:
paid them in. And in healthcare we have that
same efficiency gain the NHS used to be - I'm

386.text:
praying it still isn't - but it used to be
the biggest purchaser of fax machines in the

391.text:
world. And this was because every time someone
was discharged from hospital the hospital

396.text:
would faithfully send a fax to the GP surgery
with a discharge summary. I’m pleased to

401.text:
say now 70 per cent of trusts now do electronic
discharge summaries and so we're moving away

407.text:
from that. But those efficiency gains are
very, very important as we try to stretch

413.text:
limited resources to the increasing aspirations
that we have from the NHS. But what I want

420.text:
to argue today is that there are two very
profound ways in which again this electronic

429.text:
revolution is is quite different and one of
them Bob said very powerfully this morning

435.text:
which is there is an immediate link to clinical,
quality and safety. So if I give you an example

442.text:
10 years ago if you went to an A&E department
in this country they wouldn't have known anything

449.text:
about you and they would have then had to
make a judgement about the person who walked

453.text:
through the front door of that A&E department
purely on the basis of what they saw and obviously

459.text:
if you were unconscious that's a very difficult
process to go through. Now 77 per cent of

465.text:
A&E departments have access to the summary
care record which is actually something we’ve

471.text:
inherited from Connecting for Health, the
IT programme that Bob was talking about. And

477.text:
of course that is transformational if doctors
know your allergies; if they know that you're

484.text:
a diabetic; if they know some elements of
your medical history and so there is a direct

489.text:
impact on clinical care and safety. But there’s
another change as well which technology makes

494.text:
possible which is it puts power for the first
time really in the hands of patients. If you're

503.text:
able to Google your symptoms, information
leads to power, leads to decision-making and

510.text:
leads to autonomy. And that is a change that
some people describe as the democratisation

517.text:
of healthcare. Some people say this is going
to lead to a completely different relationship

522.text:
between doctor and patient where patients
are for the first time in the driving seat

526.text:
of their own healthcare and I want the NHS
to be absolutely at the forefront of those

533.text:
changes. I've been Health Secretary now for
4 years and 3 days and I've always been very

543.text:
enthusiastic about technology that’s why
I came up with the original Paperless 2020

550.text:
commitment but when I went to California last
year I thought it's time to actually take

554.text:
stock and I just want to say a word about
Bob because Bob I think has done a truly extraordinary

563.text:
service to the NHS with his report. I wanted
Bob to do this because and he won't mind me

571.text:
saying I think he resisted a little bit at
the start because I think he sensed that it

575.text:
was going to be a huge undertaking because
the tech world is full of visionaries who

580.text:
say the future is bright; the future is exciting;
amazing things are going to happen. There

585.text:
are many fewer people out there telling you
how things can go wrong and I'm going to give

591.text:
Bob's book a real plug here because ‘The
Digital Doctor’ is a fantastic the best

595.text:
exposition I’ve seen of how things can go
wrong; how things did go wrong in many ways

601.text:
in the US but also not losing that excitement
optimism the sense of possibility and Bob

610.text:
talked a lot about how we have a lot less
money in this country than they have in the

614.text:
US. What he was too modest to say was that
on the basis of that he agreed to do his work

620.text:
for absolutely no fees at all so that's why
I'm very happy to plug his book by way of

627.text:
a thank you but I would just like to thank
Bob his wife Katie, the Committee who worked

632.text:
extremely hard and also Harpreet Sood from
NHS England. I think they did a fantastic

637.text:
job and I think we should recognise it. [Applause]
Now one thing I said to Bob was that we do

648.text:
unfortunately in the NHS have a bit of a tradition
of very worthy reports being published in

655.text:
a blaze of publicity and then quietly gathering
dust on a shelf somewhere and never being

661.text:
implemented and Bob has cleverly made sure
this is impossible by making sure the report

667.text:
is only on-line but this is too important
to ignore and what Bob I think is very clear

675.text:
about is that we're doing well in NHS when
it comes to primary care records. He was kind

680.text:
enough to say that we are world class and
in fact 99 per cent of GP surgeries offer

686.text:
on-line appointments. 98 per cent offer the
ability to do repeat prescriptions on-line.

691.text:
97 per cent allow you to access your medical
record on-line and that combined with the

697.text:
completeness of the GP electronic record gives
us great potential for the future because

705.text:
we now have a good medical record and the
question is how we get it around the system

711.text:
and that's a good start but he was also very
direct in his message to us that our hospital

718.text:
IT systems are not up to scratch and that's
why I think his report is a sobering read

726.text:
but a very important read and so I think it's
very important that I now explain how I think

734.text:
we want to draw the lessons from what Bob
said. And I think the single biggest point

742.text:
that Bob makes about the way hospital IT systems
work is that there is huge variation in the

748.text:
system. Just as we know there’s huge variation
in clinical quality and we're making huge

753.text:
efforts to reduce that variation we still
have huge variation. I can think of an A&E

760.text:
department that I visited where a nurse told
me that two thirds of her time in the afternoon

766.text:
shift is filling out forms to get patients
admitted and in that particular hospital they

774.text:
have I think 14 different IT systems. Every
department had its own IT system. You compare

779.text:
that to somewhere not far from here Salford
Royal which has a very good IT system and

786.text:
not only that but it's interconnected with
community healthcare and the GP healthcare

792.text:
system in a way that I think is really world
class but Bob’s honest observation is that

800.text:
none of our hospital IT systems anywhere at
the moment are world class and that is not

807.text:
good enough for the NHS and that's what we
have to change; and so then the question is

812.text:
how we get there? And I think he is absolutely
right to say that people will need to go at

819.text:
different speeds. A hospital in special measures
which has severe problems with their A&E performance

826.text:
or their waiting times or whatever may not
be ready to invest in a huge IT transformation

833.text:
programme and we need to recognise that but
I think the first thing we want to do is to

837.text:
make sure that we have a group of hospitals
that by the end of this Parliament really

842.text:
do become world class; if you like an Ivy
League of hospitals. And so working with colleagues

850.text:
from NHS England and I welcome Matthew Swindells
to his job – I think he’s a fantastic

856.text:
hire, but working with colleagues from NHS
England we are able today to announce that

861.text:
Ivy League of hospitals, there may be a few
additions to this at a later stage and we're

868.text:
calling them global exemplars not because
they are global exemplars now although we

873.text:
are very proud of what they’ve done but
because our ambition for them is to become

877.text:
global exemplars in the next few years and
let me unveil the names of those trusts. And

890.text:
what does being a global exemplar mean? Well
the first thing is that they are going to

898.text:
have access to funding to some of that £4.2
billion that was allocated to this very important

905.text:
job in the spending review up to £10 million
each which will be expecting them to match

913.text:
fund and that will help to really kick start
their IT transformation programmes. We are

920.text:
also for all of them going to set up an international
partnership with a hospital or an organisation

930.text:
that we think has already got to where they
want to get to. One of the lessons we’ve

935.text:
learned from the special measures programme
under the new CQC inspection regime is that

941.text:
buddying hospitals with other hospitals that
have already done what they’re trying to

945.text:
do is a is a very effective and often a fast
way of making improvements so I'm certainly

953.text:
hoping that Bob’s hospital the University
of California San Francisco will take on one

958.text:
or two of these exemplars. But places like
the Cleveland, the Mayo, Harvard Kaiser

965.text:
Permanente - places that are absolutely world
class – we are hoping will partner with

971.text:
our hospitals in the UK in a programme to
make them absolutely up there with the best

976.text:
in the world over the next few years.
And then we have another group of hospitals;

983.text:
what Bob described as the B group, who are
ready to seriously digitise. They not be quite

993.text:
in the place that these global exemplars are
but we're going to call them national exemplars

998.text:
and we are going to invite hospitals to apply
to become a national exemplar and they will

1004.text:
get up to £5 million each initially. If they
progress they could become a global exemplar

1010.text:
so we're sort of getting our inspiration from
the champion’s league, the premiership and

1017.text:
so on. But the thing is that group of trusts
will need support and so we're going to do

1023.text:
something for the first time which I will
make a very big difference in terms of the

1029.text:
support that we offer them. We are going to
set up an NHS digital academy based at a UK

1038.text:
university that will be a centre of excellence
for helping hospitals understand the kind

1044.text:
of lessons that Bob was talking about this
morning; the things that can go right, the

1048.text:
things that can go wrong. How to make a success
of it and how to ultimately to become best

1054.text:
of class in the world and so today we are
launching a competition to find a university

1062.text:
partner for the NHS because it will be based
at a university who can host the NHS digital

1069.text:
academy and I think that's a fantastic exciting
opportunity for any university to do and let

1076.text:
me just - I put up here some of the things
that we're expecting to do but one thing in

1083.text:
particular which is one of Bob's recommendations
is to help us train a generation of clinical

1092.text:
leaders who are going to be the CCIOs of the
future and that is a big deficit in our work

1100.text:
force skills at the moment. I think one of
the great insights from Bob's book is that

1107.text:
IT transformation programmes fail if they
don't have clinical leadership and I think

1113.text:
one of the things that we have to make sure
is that every penny we spend improves doctor

1118.text:
productivity because then we’ll get doctor
buy-in, nurse buy-in to these changes so the

1125.text:
NHS Digital Academy will be a very an important
part. And then just as we have in our football

1133.text:
leagues we will have the possibilities of
promotion and relegation every year but our

1139.text:
objective is to bring everyone up to the standard
of the very best by 2023 as Bob recommends

1146.text:
in his report.
Now I just want to talk for a moment about

1152.text:
the other side to this technology revolution
which is the impact on the culture in healthcare

1160.text:
and the impact on patients and I want to put
up a picture of someone who isn't normally

1170.text:
- doesn't normally feature at Expo conferences.
Angelina Joley and the reason I put her up

1178.text:
there is not just because she's a good way
to cheer up a speech on healthcare technology

1184.text:
but because she actually did something completely
extraordinary a few years ago. She discovered

1192.text:
that her brca1 genes gave her an 87 per cent
chance of getting breast cancer. And then

1200.text:
she took two very brave decisions. The first
was to have a double mastectomy and the second

1207.text:
was to tell the world what she'd done and
why she'd done it and I think that is an incredibly

1214.text:
powerful example of patients taking control
of their own healthcare destiny and that is

1221.text:
what is going to be opened up going forward
if we can get this right. So today I want

1228.text:
to announce 4 additional things that will
really help put patients in control of their

1235.text:
own healthcare destiny and the first is around
the website My NHS which we launched a couple

1244.text:
of years ago. It has 700,000 data points.
It's the most comprehensive collection of

1249.text:
healthcare information about any healthcare
system anywhere in the world and this is where

1255.text:
people can see the quality of care at their
local hospitals, their local GP surgeries,

1260.text:
what's happening in public health in a way
that really gives people knowledge that in

1267.text:
many other healthcare systems they wouldn't
have and we are going to improve that further

1272.text:
with improved visualisation so that people
can plot the data in interesting and imaginative

1281.text:
ways. Improved customization in many areas,
but most particularly we are going to be putting

1292.text:
some new domains so this was something I actually
announced was our intention to do last year

1300.text:
but we have now given Ofsted style ratings
by CCG area in dementia, diabetes and learning

1310.text:
disabilities. And dementia we actually published
in August, diabetes and learning disabilities

1318.text:
we are publishing for the first time today,
so that people can actually see how the quality

1324.text:
of care they’re getting in their areas compares
to other areas, and over the next couple of

1328.text:
months we will be doing the same for mental
health provision and for maternity as well

1335.text:
so this is a big step forward.
The second area that we are announcing today

1344.text:
is a move towards self diagnosis. And I want
to be clear. We are going to have a new on-line

1355.text:
resource for NHS patients. What this is not
doing is ever replacing the role of the doctor

1363.text:
or a nurse or someone with clinical training
who needs to make a clinical judgement about

1369.text:
the treatment people need. But if can give
the analogy so as to be clear about what we're

1375.text:
saying. If you think about the 111 service
at the moment if you dial 111 you'll speak

1381.text:
to a trained call handler who is not clinically
qualified, and then they take you through

1388.text:
an algorithm of questions and on the basis
of your responses a judgement is made as to

1393.text:
whether you need to speak too clinician or
not. And those questions for many people would

1400.text:
be more convenient if they were done on-line
and if the result is that having gone through

1406.text:
that algorithm you need to speak to a clinician
then that's exactly what you'll do so this

1411.text:
will be moving the front end, the non-clinical
part of 111 on-line, and I think this is something

1421.text:
people will find extremely helpful. It's an
on-line resource people Google their symptoms

1426.text:
the whole time but wouldn't they like to have
something trusted and approved by the NHS

1431.text:
as a resource to give them more information.
So that's 111.

1439.text:
And then the other the third thing that we're
announcing today which again is a extremely

1448.text:
exciting development. It is now possible for
NHS patients to access their medical reports

1454.text:
on-line but you do have to go to your GP surgery
and get a password which you can then use

1460.text:
in order to do it. We're going to set up something
similar to the blue button system that they

1465.text:
have in the US where people would be able
to access their medical record on-line without

1470.text:
going into their GP surgery by identifying
themselves through a series of security questions

1477.text:
that we already use for other Government websites,
such as when you renew your driving licence

1482.text:
and my intention is to launch that service
at Expo next year but I think that will be

1489.text:
something that's really valued by many NHS
patients. And then finally we are going to

1494.text:
make a very big move in the next 12 months
into apps and wearables. I wear a Fitbit.

1501.text:
Many people use apps. What's going to change
with apps is the way that these apps link

1507.text:
directly into our own medical records and
by March next year NHS England are going to

1514.text:
publish a library of approved apps in areas
like mental health and chronic conditions

1521.text:
like diabetes. We will also in the next 12
months be having a competition because we

1526.text:
think we need better apps than the ones that
are available in the market. We don't want

1530.text:
to develop them ourselves but we want them
to be developed by entrepreneurs who have

1537.text:
specialist knowledge and the creativity to
do this and these will link in to people's

1541.text:
medical records and again we hope to announce
those at Expo next year. Let me just finish

1547.text:
by saying this I think is something this direction
of travel is something that is going to be

1553.text:
warmly welcomed by the clinical community
as well as by doctors. Clinicians know and

1559.text:
we look at evidence from things like the expert
patient programme, outcomes are better when

1564.text:
people take ownership of their own condition
and responsibility for their own condition.

1571.text:
And I just want to finish on a on a note of
optimism because I’m incredibly aware of

1578.text:
the pressures out there on the NHS front line
at the moment. When I became an MP in 2005

1588.text:
there was huge national debate about the NHS;
big protests about reconfigurations. I remember

1596.text:
Patricia Hewitt was Health Secretary at the
time. At the end of that decade that Government

1603.text:
didn’t get everything right but we did have
the lowest waiting times in the developed

1609.text:
world for elective care and emergency care.
And that was a huge achievement and I think

1615.text:
that decade will be seen as the decade when
we sorted out access to care in the NHS. In

1623.text:
this decade we’ve had to deal with financial
pressures but we’ve also had to deal with

1627.text:
Mid Staffs and we are now seeing the importance
of quality and safety becoming absolutely

1635.text:
central to everything we do in the NHS. We’ve
got the new CQC regimes, a real push towards

1642.text:
eliminating clinical variation and I think
this decade at the end of it will be seen

1647.text:
as the quality and safety decade and I think
the next decade will be - because of all this

1653.text:
technology – the patient power decade; the
decade where we use these incredible IT systems

1658.text:
to put patients in control of their own destiny.
Let me just finish with a story about Ronald

1666.text:
Reagan who was once accused, when he was President,
of being out of touch by a young student who

1673.text:
said: “you know when you were born, you
didn't have a television, you didn't have

1679.text:
space travel, you didn't have computers, you
didn't have jet engines”. And Reagan looked

1685.text:
at him and smiled and said, “Yes, you are
right, we didn't have those things. We invented

1691.text:
them”.
And I think this is our moment to invent the

1695.text:
future and make sure that we can carry on
being proud of the NHS as delivering truly

1701.text:
the best service anywhere in the world.
Thank you very much [Applause]
